issues.text: Whether the review application has become infructuous due to changes in judicial administration post-merger and Constitution, lacking authority to confirm fresh judgments under new High Court regime?

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the learned Attorney-General is that in view of the changes referred to above which had the effect of setting up a common High Court for the United State of Travancore and Cochin with jurisdiction and power defined therein, the review application has become infructuous,

issues.text: Whether the High Court majority judgments contain an error apparent on the face of the record by failing to apply mind to competency of conveners and service of notice for the Karingasserai meeting, an important issue for plaintiffs' title?

anchor.surface_text: The first objection relates to the validity of the election of the first plaintiff as the Malankara Metropolitan and as such the ex-officio trustee and the elections of plaintiffs 2 and 3 as his co-trustees at the Karingasserai meeting. This meeting is pleaded in paragraphs 13 and 14 of the plaint,

issues.text: Whether the High Court majority judgments are vitiated by misconception of the concession/argument made by defendants' advocate that plaintiffs had not left the church, failing to examine plaintiffs' acts under issues 14,15,19,20, amounting to sufficient reason analogous to error apparent for review?

Whether the High Court erred by taking adverse view on matters agreed to be left out regarding issue 11(a) (general powers of Patriarch), not covered by pleadings or issues, amounting to error apparent on the face of the record?

holdings.text: In our opinion, therefore, the preliminary objection cannot prevail and must be rejected.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, the preliminary objection cannot prevail and must be rejected. Before going into the merits of the case it is as well to bear in mind the scope of the application for review which has given rise to the present appeal. It is needless to emphasise that the scope of an application for review is much more restricted than that of an appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Review application properly instituted under old law and pending; continues in successor High Court under s.8 Ordinance II 1124 and s.8 Act 1125; revived appeal disposed under s.25 without Maharaja confirmation; old s.11/12 apply as far as possible, confirmation inapplicable post political changes.

holdings.text: The majority judgments, therefore, are defective on the face of them in that they did not effectively deal with and determine an important issue in the case on which depends the title of the plaintiffs and the maintainability of the suit. This, in our opinion, is certainly an error apparent on the face of the record.

anchor.surface_text: The majority judgments, therefore, are defective on the face of them in that they did not effectively deal with and determine an important issue in the case on which depends the title of the plaintiffs and the maintainability of the suit. This, in our opinion, is certainly an error apparent on the face of the. record. The next point urged by learned counsel appearing for the appellants is that the majority decision proceeds on a misconception as to a concession said to have been made by the defendants advocate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court majority failed to apply mind to competency of conveners and notice to all churches for Karingasserai meeting, key to plaintiffs' trustee title under issue 1(b); judgments superficial and defective on face.

holdings.text: In our opinion it is permissible to rely on the affidavit as an additional ground for review of the judgment.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion it is permissible to rely on the affidavit as an additional ground for review of the judgment. Turning to the affidavit and the letters and the ground No. 17 of review it is quite obvious that the defendants had not given -up their contention, upheld by the District Judge, that the plaintiffs had been guilty of the acts and conduct imputed to them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Misconception of concession/argument by court analogous to error apparent; affidavit and supporting letters permissible in review to show misconception of record, per Privy Council, Federal Court, and Madras HC precedents.

holdings.text: In our opinion, for reasons stated above, this head of objection raised by the learned advocate for the appellants before us is well-founded and the judgments of the majority Judges are vitiated by an error of a kind which is sufficient reason within the meaning of the Code of Civil Procedure for allowing the review.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, for reasons stated above, this head of objection raised by the learned advocate for the appellants before us is well-founded and the judgments of the majority Judges are vitiated by an error of a kind which is sufficient reason within the meaning of the Code of Civil Procedure for allowing the review. The last point taken up by the learned advocate for the appellants is that although certain matters had been agreed to be left out in connection with issue No. 11 a , the learned Judges took an adverse view against the defendants on matters which had been so left out by agreement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court majority misled by misconception of defendants' advocate concession re plaintiffs not leaving church; failed to examine plaintiffs' acts under issues 14,15,19,20 re heresy vs voluntary separation; analogous to error apparent per Judicial Committee.

holdings.text: To decide against a party on matters which do not come within the issues on which the parties went to trial clearly amounts to an error apparent on the face of the record.
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court decided against defendants on unpleaded/unissued matters under issue 11(a) (obey Patriarch installation-independent, faith decisions, Catholicos approval) agreed to leave out; error apparent on face.

holdings.text: In our opinion the appellants have made out a valid ground for allowing their application for review. We accordingly allow this appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and admit the review.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the appellants have made out a valid ground for allowing their application for review. We accordingly allow this appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and admit the review. As the different points involved in this appeal are intimately interconnected we direct the entire appeal to be reheard on all points unless both parties accept any of the findings of the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Errors apparent and analogous sufficient reasons established; review admitted, High Court judgment set aside, original appeal to be reheard fully.

holdings.text: Under the provisions in the Travancore Code of Civil Procedure which is similar in terms to Order XLVII, rule I of our Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, the Court of review has only a limited jurisdiction circumscribed by the definitive limits fixed by the language used therein.

anchor.surface_text: Under the provisions in the Travancore Code of Civil Procedure which is similar in terms to Order XLVII, rule I of our Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, the Court of review has only a limited jurisdiction circumscribed by the definitive limits fixed by the language used therein. It may allow a review on three specified, grounds, namely (i) discovery of new and important matter or evidence which, after the exercise of due diligence, was not within the applicants knowledge or could not be produced by him at the time when the decree was. passed, (ii) mistake or error apparent on the face of the record and (iii) for any other sufficient reason.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Review jurisdiction limited to discovery of new evidence, error apparent on face, or analogous sufficient reason per Judicial Committee interpretation.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, the preliminary objection cannot prevail and must be rejected. Before going into the merits of the case it is as well to bear in mind the scope of the application for review which has given rise to the present appeal. It is needless to emphasise that the scope of an application for review is much more restricted than that of an appeal.

In our opinion the appellants have made out a valid ground for allowing their application for review. We accordingly allow this appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and admit the review. As the different points involved in this appeal are intimately interconnected we direct

anchor.surface_text: The majority judgments, therefore, are defective on the face of them in that they did not effectively deal with and determine an important issue in the case on which depends the title of the plaintiffs and the maintainability of the suit. This, in our opinion, is certainly an error apparent on the face of the. record. The next point urged by learned counsel appearing for the appellants is that the majority decision proceeds on a misconception as to a concession said to have been made by the defendants advocate.

In our opinion the appellants have made out a valid ground for allowing their application for review. We accordingly allow this appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and admit the review. As the different points involved in this appeal are intimately interconnected we direct

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion it is permissible to rely on the affidavit as an additional ground for review of the judgment. Turning to the affidavit and the letters and the ground No. 17 of review it is quite obvious that the defendants had not given -up their contention, upheld by the District Judge, that the plaintiffs had been guilty of the acts and conduct imputed to them.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, for reasons stated above, this head of objection raised by the learned advocate for the appellants before us is well-founded and the judgments of the majority Judges are vitiated by an error of a kind which is sufficient reason within the meaning of the Code of Civil Procedure for allowing the review. The last point taken up by the learned advocate for the appellants is that although certain matters had been agreed to be left out in connection with issue No. 11 a , the learned Judges took an adverse view against the defendants on matters which had been so left out by agreement.

In our opinion the appellants have made out a valid ground for allowing their application for review. We accordingly allow this appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and admit the review. As the different points involved in this appeal are intimately interconnected we direct
